An EDAM CV term ID identifying the compression format of this file (e.g. gzip or bzip2): null if this file is not compressed
An EDAM CV term ID identifying the type of information stored in this file (e.g. RNA sequence reads): null if is_bundle is set to true
An OBI CV term ID describing the type of experiment that generated the results summarized by this file
An OBI CV term ID describing the type of analytic operation that generated this file
A MIME type describing this file

If this file is a bundle encoding more than one sub-file, this field gives the local_id of a collection listing the bundle's sub-file contents; null otherwise
The name of a dbGaP study ID governing access control for this file, compatible for comparison to RAS user-level access control metadata

values: The Metabolomics Workbench is the NIH Common Fund's National Metabolomics Data Repository (NMDR). The Metabolomics Workbench accepts metabolomics data for small and large studies on cells, tissues and organisms. We can accommodate a variety of metabolite analyses, including, but not limited to MS and NMR. In order to ensure reproducibility and interoperable use of data, we require experimental metadata to be deposited along with the metabolite measurements. Processed data (measurements) maybe in the form of quantitated metabolite concentrations, MS peak height/area values, LC retention times, NMR binned areas, etc. Raw data in the form of MS and NMR binary files and associated parameter files may also be uploaded. We accept data from both targeted and untargeted studies. The Metabolomics Workbench also provides a suite of tools for analysis and visualization of the data.

values: An assay that identifies the amount and type of material entities present in a sample by fragmenting the sample and measuring the mass-to-charge ratio of the resulting particles.

An assay that exploits the magnetic properties of certain nuclei (those with a spin) to resonate when placed in particular magnetic field conditions. Instruments recording NMR spectrum and sets of analysis can be used to deduce identity of chemical as well as composition of complex chemical mixtures.

A mass spectrometry assay where a sample mixture is first separated by liquid chromatography before being converted into ions which are characterized by using mass spectrometry based on their mass-to-charge ratio and relative abundance.
A mass spectrometry assay combining mass spectrometry and gas chromatography for the qualitative as well as quantitative determination of compounds.

values: Peak matching is a data transformation performed on a dataset of a graph of ordered data points (e.g. a spectrum) with the objective of pattern matching local maxima above a noise threshold
A data transformation which has the objective of spectrum analysis.
Gas chromatography mass spectrometry is a data transformation combining mass spectrometry and   gas chromatography for the qualitative as well as quantitative   determinations of compounds.

values: The fluid surrounding the ovum and granulosa cells in the ovarian follicle.

Amniotic fluid is a bodily fluid consisting of watery liquid surrounding and cushioning a growing fetus within the amnion. It allows the fetus to move freely without the walls of the uterus being too tight against its body. Buoyancy is also provided. The composition of the fluid changes over the course of gestation. Initially, amniotic fluid is similar to maternal plasma, mainly water with electrolytes. As the fetus develops, proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, phospholipids originating from the lungs, fetal cells, and urea are deposited in the fluid.
A fluid that is composed of blood plasma and erythrocytes.

Interstitial fluid is a bodily fluid consisting of a solution which bathes and surrounds the cells of multicellular animals. It is the main component of the extracellular fluid, which also includes plasma and transcellular fluid.
Excretion that is the output of a kidney.
Secretion produced by a sweat gland.
Transudate contained in the peritoneal cavity.
A clear, colorless, bodily fluid, that occupies the subarachnoid space and the ventricular system around and inside the brain and spinal cord.
A thick watery refractive medium that fills the space between the lens and the cornea.
A fluid produced in the oral cavity by salivary glands, typically used in predigestion, but also in other functions.
An emulsion of fat globules within a fluid that is secreted by the mammary gland during lactation.
The liquid component of blood, in which erythrocytes are suspended.
The portion of blood plasma that excludes clotting factors.
Portion of semisolid bodily waste discharged through the anus.
A substance formed from the secretion of one or more glands of the male genital tract in which sperm cells are suspended.
Matter ejected from the lungs, bronchi, and trachea, through the mouth.
An aqueous substance that covers the anterior surface of the eyeball, keeping the cornea wet.

values: The Metabolomics Workbench is the NIH Common Fund's National Metabolomics Data Repository (NMDR). The Metabolomics Workbench accepts metabolomics data for small and large studies on cells, tissues and organisms. We can accommodate a variety of metabolite analyses, including, but not limited to MS and NMR. In order to ensure reproducibility and interoperable use of data, we require experimental metadata to be deposited along with the metabolite measurements. Processed data (measurements) maybe in the form of quantitated metabolite concentrations, MS peak height/area values, LC retention times, NMR binned areas, etc. Raw data in the form of MS and NMR binary files and associated parameter files may also be uploaded. We accept data from both targeted and untargeted studies. The Metabolomics Workbench also provides a suite of tools for analysis and visualization of the data.
